content.body: do we have any prior art of built-in functions doing something different when _all_ parameters are undefined? like, not just default values for certain undefined parameters, but a special overload for the nullary case

content.body: If someone wants to pick up standardizing all the edge cases of the Date constructor, I think that'd be a very important project.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: If someone wants to pick up standardizing all the edge cases of the Date constructor, I think that'd be a very important project.

content.body: Which edge cases haven't been standardized?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Which edge cases haven't been standardized?

content.body: all the non-ISO8601 ones!
this is a major point of compatibility issues between JS implementations
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: this is a major point of compatibility issues between JS implementations

content.body: Ah, so Date.parse really.
* Ah, so Date.parse really.

it will be challenging to find the right set of things to interpret in practice to be compatible enough, but browsers have expressed appetite to upgrade to something if it's web-compatible in practice
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: it will be challenging to find the right set of things to interpret in practice to be compatible enough, but browsers have expressed appetite to upgrade to something if it's web-compatible in practice

content.body: hi! in test262 we have an [RFC](https://github.com/tc39/test262/pull/3724) open (our first, as a trial of a new RFC process) about adding some facilities to test262 for improving the experience of writing asynchronous tests. we'd love to have some feedback from the perspective of implementers maintaining a test262 runner, and from (potential) test writers.
